data.prompt:
Extract comprehensive customer insights from reviews about Toggle Style Dimmer Switches.
The output format is JSON in English:
{
"phy": {
"<PHYSICAL>": {
"<PID>@<DETAIL>": {
"<SENT>": [ID, …]
}
}
},
"perf": {
"<PERF>": {
"<perf_id>@<DETAIL>": {
"<SENT>": {<PERF_REASON>: [ID, …]}
}
}
},
"use": {
"<USE>": {
"<SENT>": {<USE_REASON>: [ID, …]}
}
}
}

Definitions:
- <PID>: Unique ID for physical aspect ("phy"), starting from A. After Z, continue with AA, AB, and so on.
- <PHYSICAL>: Components or inherent physical properties of the Toggle Style Dimmer Switches without external interaction (e.g. dimensions, appearance, material type...)
- <DETAIL>: A self-contained detail summarized from the reviews.
- <SENT>: Sentiment polarity of the current <DETAIL> (- for negative, + for positive).
- ID: All review IDs mentioning the <DETAIL>
- <perf_id>: Unique ID for performance or functions ("perf"), starting from a. After z, continue with aa, ab, and so on.
- <PERF>: The Toggle Style Dimmer Switches' performance (e.g. flexibility, durability, ...) or behaviors under various conditions (e.g. temperature, force, chemicals...) without reference to any specific use case
- <PERF_REASON>: <PID> of the <PHYSICAL> explicitly mentioned as the cause of the <PERF>. Include all mentioned <PID>s. If no reason is mentioned, use "?". <PERF_REASON> and <PERF> should have the same sentiment polarity in the review where they are mentioned together (i.e. the same review ID are included at both locations)
- <USE>: The specific application, applicable object, method, tool, or environment for the product.
- <USE_REASON>: <perf_id> or <PID> causing the <USE>'s sentiment. Include all mentioned reasons, or "?" if none can be inferred. <USE_REASON> and <USE> should have the same sentiment polarity in the review where they are mentioned together.

CRITICAL INSTRUCTIONS:
- <PHYSICAL>/<PERF> and <DETAIL> MUST NOT include:
  * Generic statements without details (e.g., "good", "bad quality")
  * Issues unrelated to the product itself (e.g., "fast shipping", "delivery time")
- If a review mentions any physical aspect, related performance, or use together, extract them as separate entries under "phy," "perf," and "use," with no overlap.
- Make sure each <DETAIL> is under the most relevant <PHYSICAL> or <PERF> in the context of Toggle Style Dimmer Switches
- Preserve negations

Key Instructions:
- Break down reviews with multiple aspects, performances, or uses into individual entries.
- Escape special characters with backslash that could cause JSON syntax errors.
- Include only explicitly mentioned reasons, and use "?" where no reason is mentioned.

Final Checklist:
- Go through all reviews and ensure that no aspect, performance, use, or reason is omitted, even if only mentioned once.
- Review all entries to ensure proper separation between aspects, performances, and uses.

Print the JSON result only.
Input format:
<ID>#<review>

[[INPUT]]
0#Dimmer - it works and is just as good as more expensive ones. Simple to install and is working really well! My wife hated how bright our bathroom was in the vending, with a chandelier with 4 light bulbs in even 40W made it feel like the sun was gonna burn your eyes out. Finally got this thing installed and now we don’t get blinded by the light :)
1#Dimmable switch was a nice change. Switch works great, was able to dim the lights without any issues. Nice to have options
2#Too LOUD for me! It's going back. The loudest light switch since the 1950s-1960s I've ever heard. Unless you're hard of hearing or deaf, don't buy it. Fortunately I tested it right out of the box and haven't installed it yet. It's going back on the same day it arrived.
3#Work well with decent bulbs. Bought two of these to replace existing (circa. 2004) wall dimmers which were not LED compatible. I'm using these with GE brand dimmable LED bulbs and everything is working perfectly - Dimming very smoothly & consistently throughout the brightness range. It was annoying to have to replace my old dimmer switches to support LED bulbs, but I am very happy with this purchase.
4#Does not work with dimmable LED. Although they claim it works with dimmable LEDs it does not. The light flashes in high setting. Spend the money on Lutron that does work
5#Flicker with LED lamps. This dimmer will flicker with LED lamps. I replaced with a Lutron dimmer that does not flicker. Even though it says that this dimmer is compatible it is not. Do not buy this dimmer. Past my return window by a couple of weeks so it is just a $16 piece of trash for me.
6#Better use EARPLUGS before you turn on your lights! It works, but is THE LOUDEST, CLICKIEST toggle switch that I’ve ever used, in my home or anywhere else!
7#Flicker with LED lights, cheap flimsy product. I expected better from a name brand GE dimmer. Nope. They flickered under cabinet lights, also flickering on overhead lights. Three fixtures flickered. 3 out of 4 dimmers I bought had the same issue. Leviton is more expensive, but they simply work. time saved = money in your pocket.
8#Smooth operation. Very nice dimmer. Easy install, simple operation, and reasonable cost.
9#Good price. This dimmer switch was a good price. Easy to install and works as described. Just installed 1/15/25, so hopefully there will be no problems. Such cheaper than other brands that has same features.
10#Fixed LED Flicker. I bought this dimmer to replace my old dimmer which was causing my LED lights to flicker when dimming them. It fixed the problem. Highly recommend if you need to stop your LED bulbs from flickering when they're dimmed.
11#Works as it should. Works as it should.
12#Slider Vs. Rotary Dimmer. Slider moves too easily when you switch on. Since purchase I have replaced it with a rotary Dimmer Switch.
13#Nice dimmer switch. I bought more.
14#Dimmer. Lamps still flicker. Tried different bulbs. No help
15#It was easy to install. Took less than 10 min to install
16#I swear the lights don't get as bright with no dimming as a regular switch; dimming is wonky. I have dim-capable LED lighting on the ceiling. Originally had just a regular switch. Flip, lights full blast. When I put this switch in, flip on with "no dim" and I swear they are all of a sudden not as bright as the regular switch. Maybe I'm seeing things? But then I go to test dimming and it reacts extremely slowly. You have to operate the dim slider at a glacial pace to have any fidelity in the dimming. It's not ideal. I have another dimmer switch from Lutron I'm going to slap in to see what happens tonight. On the positives, the switch operation is very tactile... clunky and positive (unlike many switches sold today that are gummy), it's not ridiculously deep, and it uses screw terminals instead of those incredibly annoying and cheap aluminum wires that just force a crowded electrical box thanks to tons of wire nuts.
17#Worked as advertised. Love the ability to dim my lights
18#Good dimmer. Works as expected. Easy installation, no problems in over 2 months of using it
19#Stopped working after 2 days. I had this switch installed by an electrician to control an LED ceiling fixture. It worked fine initially and then when I switched it on a couple days later, the light would not come on. Had my electrician come back to look at it. He found there was power going into the switch but no power coming out. He replaced it with a Leviton Sureslide dimmer switch, and now all is well.
20#POS do not buy! Bought 3 of these for my new house. Can leds and pendant lamps. 1 failed within 3 days and the other within 45 days. no Amazon return after 30 days and no support from GE. POS.
21#Works as a dimmer switch. Not the easiest switch I have ever installed as the ground screw would not drop enough to wrap the ground wire around it. Also the push in connections for the other leads must be locked in place with a screw. Kinda weird.
22#It works well. Works well, good price
23#Not as pictured. Instead of a big dimming toggle switch....it consists of an on/off snap switch....and an additional small slider switch.
24#Know what you are doing. The instructions for three way hook up are vague so I had to do a couple of tries at first. They work well enough, when you turn them on they tend to raise the brightness level along with the power on. Not a big deal.
25#Excellent LED dimmer. Using this for our track light. Switched to LED from halogen. No flicker and simple installation
26#Product is garbage. installed the dimmer and the dimmer function does NOT work, switch only turns the lights "on" and "off" , there is no working dimmer function on this light switch, it came defective.
27#Basic Dimming. Worked great and simple design. Easy to install.
28#This LED compatible dimmer works great! I used these for dimmable LED ceiling lights. It works perfectly. It's very easy to adjust the minimum point with the adjustment button. I'm impressed and will buy again
29#OK value. Would have expected more from GE. The terminals are loose and hard to wire unless you hold it upside down. There is also a delay before the LED lights turn on.
30#Nice Switch. These switches work great. Worth the money. The switch is silent and the dimmer slide moves easily. A bit too easy really. If your not careful, every time you turn the switch on or off you will move the dimmer portion of the switch as well, causing you to have to readjust the brightness of the light every time you use the switch.
31#Use with GE led bulbs for best performance. This is an excellent switch for LED bulbs BUT the performance is best when it’s used with GE LED BULBS!!! Specifically the relax and reveal line bulbs!!! Hopefully many people see this review so they can enjoy the range of this dimmer , I’d bet this dims as low as halogen bulbs used to dim when you pair it with GE DIMMABLE LED BULBS!!! A highly recommended switch from me and I have probably 7 of these in our home!
32#Easy to drill into ceramic. Turn items into plant pots Just add water in bottom of pot Start on a slight slant and gradually go straight on. Worked great Dry off after using so bit doesn't rust Very happy
33#As described. Reviews worried me but once I received the swith and installed it I was relieved. Quality switch and works great. No flickering or anything..
34#Poor Dimming Range. I installed it, and immediately removed it. It works - but 90% of the dimming range occurs within the briefest movement of the toggle. If you move it VERY carefully you can set dimming at roughy 40% of brightness, but move it a fraction more and it jumps to 90% of brightness - the rest of the motion changes the brightness very little. In addition, the toggle has no resistance - it moves to easily. It worked - but I wouldn't use it.
35#Great! Dimmer Switch LED that is working very well.
36#Old school toggle dimmer. Just got this and installed immediately...very pleased with results with two incandescent floods. This dimmer is old school toggle switch only (no small slider on the side), that's what I wanted. An FYI, fairly big (I imagine it has a circuit board with an IC PWM in it): I mention the size, because it is a tight squeeze in a metal single gang box....but, don't worry......I made it fit. Will be no squeeze at all for use in a single gang blue plastic box.
37#Horrible quality, feels like its going to fall apart. Super cheap quality. I don't understand how the United States could allow something so flimsy to be used in electrical systems. I doubt this will last a year before breaking. Unfortunately, it's Thanksgiving and I have people coming over so I won't be returning it.
38#Toggle dimmer switch. Shipped quickly and was so simple to install! Works great!
39#Works great. Works as described
40#Oldie but goodie! Client wanted the same kind of dimmer switch, they did not like the newer ones. Luckily these were available since the other look like this one, but it uses a slider to dimmer. These units dim/in/off using the switch alone. Great find.
41#(POORLY) MADE IN CHINA! After installing this replacement toggle dimmer the LED bulbs flickered annoyingly. They worked perfectly with the previous toggle dimmer of another brand which had died after many years of use. Luckily I still had a stash of 60W clear incandescent bulbs so I swapped them out. 2nd issue was when I tried to reinstall the cover plate screws. Despite being carefully lined up they wouldn't even start. A closer look showed that the holes would not accept a 6-32 screw, which has been the USA standard for such screws for decades. Luckily I have an extensive set of machinist taps and was able to properly thread the hole but no one should have to do this. The switch action also feels of low quality and I suspect it will wear out sooner than it should. Bottom Line: Save your money and buy a better brand such as Pass & Seymour.
42#It's what I wanted... I wanted to replace my existing switches with separate dimming rheostats with a single switch type. These did the trick! They're a bit more costly than I liked but they're a one time expense.
43#Blinking lights. Caused dimmable led lights to blink, tried a different style (knob) dimmer and it works.
44#nice. good value for the dollars spent
45#works great, no little slider on the side. This dimmer is different from most, in that there is no little slider on the side of the switch. You just move the lever to adjust the level. That's the way I like it.
46#Was great until it broke. It was a great switch and easy to install, but only lasted a little over a year.
47#Broken after 1 year. Bought two of these and they are both broken within 1 year of usage. Learn from our experience and don’t buy these.
48#Limited value. It might work fine in some applications, but it gives very troublesome flickers at some positions when used in my pretty standard under-cabinet light strip. Replacing with a brand that was just a bit more expensive solved the problem. Also, the switch itself has a loose, "cheap" feel.
49#Malfunction after 2 1/2 years. Installed to operate an LED fixture over the tub/shower in the main bathroom that is shard by two persons. Usage would be 4 or 5 times a week. After 2 1/2 years the switch failed. Up until then it was great at being able to choose brightness by just the on/off toggle and not having a secondary slider next to the toggle. Bad design or quality control issues? Other switches used to last for decades with higher usage. Just another sign of the times and something we have to accept with so much manufacturing being contracted to third parties overseas and clouded by using formerly strong recognizable U.S. company names.
